facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 150 of 1954 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 150 of 1954. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 21, 1950, of the

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated March 21, 1950, of the Court of Judicial Commissioner at Ajmer in Civil First Appeal No. 13 of 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 21, 1950, of the Court of Judicial Commissioner at Ajmer in Civil First Appeal No. 13 of 1948, arising out of the judgment and decree dated March 30, 1948,

facts.text: Arising out of judgment and decree dated March 30, 1948, of the Court of Sub-Judge 1st Class, Ajmer, in Civil Suit No. I of 1947.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and decree dated March 30, 1948, of the Court of Sub-Judge 1st Class, Ajmer, in Civil Suit No. I of 1947. Tarachand Brijmohan Lal, for the appellant. S. Deedwania and K. L. Mehta,

facts.text: Suit for redemption of mortgage dated August 1, 1899.

anchor.surface_text: SARKAR J.-This appeal arises out of a suit for the redemption of a mortgage dated August 1, 1899. The property mortgaged was a four-roomed shop with certain appurtenances, standing on a piece of land measuring 5 yards by 15 yards in Naya Bazar, Ajmere.

facts.text: Property mortgaged was a four-roomed shop with certain appurtenances on land measuring 5 yards by 15 yards in Naya Bazar, Ajmere.

anchor.surface_text: The property mortgaged was a four-roomed shop with certain appurtenances, standing on a piece of land measuring 5 yards by 15 yards in Naya Bazar, Ajmere. The mortgage was created by Purshottamdas who is long dead and was in favour of Dhanrupmal, a respondent in this appeal.

facts.text: Mortgage created by Purshottamdas (long dead) in favour of Dhanrupmal.

anchor.surface_text: The mortgage was created by Purshottamdas who is long dead and was in favour of Dhanrupmal, a respondent in this appeal. The mortgage instrument stated that the property had been usufructuarily mortgaged in lieu of Rs. 6,300 of which Rs. 5,750 had been left with the mortgagee to redeem a prior mortgage on the same and another property.

facts.text: Usufructuary mortgage in lieu of Rs. 6,300, of which Rs. 5,750 left with mortgagee to redeem prior mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: The mortgage instrument stated that the property had been usufructuarily mortgaged in lieu of Rs. 6,300 of which Rs. 5,750 had been left with the mortgagee to redeem a prior mortgage on the same and another property. It also provided that on redemption of the prior mortgage, the possession of the shop would be taken over and retained by the mortgagee, Dhanrupmal, who would appropriate its rent in lieu of interest on the money advanced by him and the possession of the other property covered by the prior mortgage, being a share in a Kacheri would be made over to the mortgagor, Purshottamdas.

facts.text: Mortgage provisions: mortgagor or heirs not entitled to redeem for 85 years; after expiry, redeem within 6 months or no claim, deed deemed sale.

anchor.surface_text: The provisions in the mortgage instrument on which the present dispute turns were in these terms I or my heirs will not be entitled to redeem the property for a period of 85 years. After the expiry of 85 years we shall redeem it within a period of six months. In case we do not redeem within a period of six months, then after the expiry of the stipulated period, I, my heirs, and legal representatives shall have no claim over the mortgaged property, and the mortgagee shall have no claim to get the mortgage money and the lagat i.e., repairs expenses that may be due at the time of default. In such case, this very deed will be deemed to be a sale deed.

facts.text: Dhanrupmal redeemed the prior mortgage, took possession of the shop, delivered possession of Kacheri to Purshottamdas.

anchor.surface_text: The mortgagee, Dhanrupmal, duly redeemed the earlier mortgage and, went into possession of the shop while possession of the Kacheri was delivered to the mortgagor. On April 12, 1939, Dhanrupmal assigned his rights under the mortgage to Motilal who died later, and whose estate is now represented by his sons, who are the other respondents in this appeal.

facts.text: On April 12, 1939, Dhanrupmal assigned mortgage rights to Motilal.

anchor.surface_text: On April 12, 1939, Dhanrupmal assigned his rights under the mortgage to Motilal who died later, and whose estate is now represented by his sons, who are the other respondents in this appeal. The estate of Purshottamdas, the original mortgagor, is now represented by his son, the appellant.

facts.text: Motilal died, estate represented by his sons (respondents).

anchor.surface_text: to Motilal who died later, and whose estate is now represented by his sons, who are the other respondents in this appeal. The estate of Purshottamdas, the original mortgagor, is now represented by his son, the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant is son of Purshottamdas, represents his estate.

anchor.surface_text: The estate of Purshottamdas, the original mortgagor, is now represented by his son, the appellant. On January 2, 1947, the appellant filed the suit in the Court of the Sub-Judge, Ajmere, against the respondents.

facts.text: On January 2, 1947, appellant filed suit for redemption in Court of Sub-Judge, Ajmer.

anchor.surface_text: On January 2, 1947, the appellant filed the suit in the Court of the Sub-Judge, Ajmere, against the respondents. The suit was contested by the sons of Motilal, the assignee of the mortgage, who are the only respondents appearing in this appeal and whom we shall hence, hereafter refer to as the respondents.

facts.text: Respondents contested suit as premature, no right of redemption till August 1, 1984.

anchor.surface_text: They said that the suit was premature as under the mortgage contract there was no right of redemption for eighty five years after the date of the mortgage, that is to say, till August 1, 1984. The learned Sub-Judge, purporting to follow a decision of the Judicial Commissioner, Ajmere, to whom he was subordinate, held that the provision postponing redemption for eightyfive years was invalid as it amounted to a clog on the equity of redemption.

facts.text: Sub-Judge held 85-year postponement invalid as clog on equity of redemption, passed preliminary decree for redemption.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sub-Judge, purporting to follow a decision of the Judicial Commis- sioner, Ajmere, to whom he was subordinate, held that the provision postponing redemption for eightyfive years was invalid as it amounted to a clog on the equity of redemption. He, therefore, passed a preliminary decree for redemption.

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner reversed Sub-Judge, held provision not a clog, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the learned Judicial Commissioner, Ajmere, held, that the decision which the Sub-Judge had purported to follow was, distinguishable. He examined a large number of cases on the subject and came to the conclusion that the provision in question did not amount to a clog on the equity of redemption. He, therefore, allowed the appeal and dismissed the appellants suit.

facts.text: Case governed by Transfer of Property Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that the case is governed by the Transfer of Property Act.

facts.text: Suit brought over 47 years after mortgage date.

anchor.surface_text: The suit for redemption was brought over forty-seven years after the date of the mortgage. It seems to us impossible that if the term was oppressive, that was not realised much earlier and the suit brought within a short time of the mortgage.

facts.text: Supreme Court held 85-year term not a clog, enforceable; suit premature.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, think that the bargain was a reasonable one and the eighty-five years term of the mortgage should be enforced. We then come to the conclusion that the suit was premature and must fail.

facts.text: 6-month redemption window provision invalid as it takes away right to redeem after period.

anchor.surface_text: One thing, therefore, is clear, namely, that the term in the mortgage contract, that on the failure of the mortgagor to redeem the mortgage within the specified period of six months the mortgagor will have no claim over the mortgaged property, and the mortgage deed will be deemed to be a deed of sale in favour of the mortgagee, cannot be sustained.

facts.text: Property subject to prior mortgage, which included another property (Kacheri share).

anchor.surface_text: It also provided that on redemption of the prior mortgage, the possession of the shop would be taken over and retained by the mortgagee, Dhanrupmal, who would appropriate its rent in lieu of interest on the money advanced by him and the possession of the other property covered by the prior mortgage, being a share in a Kacheri would be made over to the mortgagor, Purshottamdas.

facts.text: Interest to be appropriated from rent of shop.

anchor.surface_text: who would appropriate its rent in lieu of interest on the money advanced by him

facts.text: No complaint that interest rate (measured by rent) was high.

anchor.surface_text: Again, no complaint is made that the interest charged, which was to be measured by the rent of the property, was in any manner high.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 15, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Tarachand Brijmohan Lal, for the appellant. S. Deedwania and K. L. Mehta, for the respondents. 1958. April 15.

Under s. 60 of that Act, at any time after the principal money has become due, the mortgagor has a right on payment or tender of the mortgage money to require the mortgagee to reconvey the mortgage property to him. The right conferred by this section has been called the right to redeem and the appellant sought to enforce this right by his suit. Under this section, however, that right can be exercised only after the mortgage money has become due.

concepts.interpretation: Gives mortgagor right to redeem after principal becomes due; right cannot be extinguished once arisen; unqualified terms apply fully.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: said in Mohammad Sher Khan v. Seth Swami Dayal  2  An anomalous mortgage enabling a mortgagee after a lapse of time and in the absence of redemption

concepts.unlisted_description: Mortgagor's right to require reconveyance on payment of mortgage money after it becomes due

concepts.unlisted_label: Clog on the equity of redemption
concepts.unlisted_description: Invalid provision limiting or extinguishing mortgagor's right to redeem

anchor.surface_text: The rule against clogs on the equity of redemption is that, a mortgage shall always be redeemable and a mortgagors right to redeem shall neither be taken away nor be limited by any contract between the parties. The principle behind the rule was expressed by Lindley M. R. in Santley v. Wilde 1 in these words The principle is this a mortgage is a conveyance of land or an assignment of chattles as a security for the payment of a debt or the discharge of some other obligation for which it is given. This is the idea of a mortgage and the security is redeemable on the payment or discharge of such debt or obligation, any provision to the contrary notwithstanding.

concepts.interpretation: Mortgage always redeemable; no contract can take away or limit right to redeem; 6-month default clause invalid as it extinguishes right after period; 85-year term merely postpones accrual and not clog if not unconscionable.

anchor.surface_text: It follows from this, that once a mortgage always a mortgage . The right of redemption, therefore, cannot be taken away.

concepts.interpretation: Mortgage remains redeemable regardless of contrary provisions.

anchor.surface_text: This is not permissible, for once a mortgage always a mortgage and therefore always redeemable.

anchor.surface_text: The right conferred by this section has been called the right to redeem and the appellant sought to enforce this right by his suit.

concepts.interpretation: Arises only when principal money becomes due; continues even after short redemption windows; enforceable by suit after due date.

concepts.unlisted_description: Mortgagor's statutory right under TPA s.60 to redeem mortgaged property

anchor.surface_text: An anomalous mortgage enabling a mortgagee after a lapse of time and in the absence of redemption to enter and take the rents in satisfaction of the interest. would be perfectly valid if it did not also hinder an existing right to redeem. But it is this that the present mortgage undoubtedly purports to effect.

concepts.unlisted_description: Mortgage not fitting standard categories, valid unless hinders redemption right

anchor.surface_text: The rule against clogs on the equity of redemption no doubt involves that the Courts have the power to relieve a party from his bargain. If he has agreed to forfeit wholly his right to redeem in certain circumstances, that agreement will be avoided. But the Courts have gone beyond this. They have also relieved mortgagors from bargains whereby the right to redeem has not been taken away but restricted.

concepts.interpretation: Court examines if term oppressive, if mortgagor imposed upon or oppressed due to necessity/embarrassment; considers facts like term length, interest, circumstances, prior mortgages, delay in suit; here, no unconscionability found for 85-year term.

concepts.unlisted_description: Whether bargain unconscionable, taking advantage of mortgagor's difficulties

anchor.surface_text: In a very early case, namely, Vermon v. Bethell Earl of Northington L. C. said, This Court, as a Court of conscience, is very jealous of persons taking securities for a loan, and converting such securities into purchases. And therefore I take it to be an established rule, that a mortgagee can never provide at the time of making the loan for any event or condition on which the equity of redemption shall be discharged, and the conveyance absolute.

concepts.interpretation: Equity relieves against unconscionable terms converting security to absolute purchase, originating from suspicion of moneylending.

issues.text: Whether the suit for redemption is premature as the 85-year term of the mortgage has not expired and the principal money has not become due

anchor.surface_text: Now, in the present case the term of the mortgage is eighty- five years and there is no stipulation entitling the mortgagor to redeem during that term. That term has not yet expired. The respondents, therefore, contend that the suit is premature and liable to be dismissed.

arguments.court_reasoning: Term fixes due date, postpones accrual of right; valid unless unconscionable; no oppression shown

arguments.claim: Term limiting redemption to 6 months after 85 years, failing which no claim and deed deemed sale, cannot be sustained as it takes away right to redeem

anchor.surface_text: One thing, therefore, is clear, namely, that the term in the mortgage contract, that on the failure of the mortgagor to redeem the mortgage within the specified period of six months the mortgagor will have no claim over the mortgaged property, and the mortgage deed will be deemed to be a deed of sale in favour of the mortgagee, cannot be sustained.

arguments.claim: Once a mortgage always a mortgage; right to redeem cannot be taken away or limited by contract

anchor.surface_text: The rule against clogs on the equity of redemption is that, a mortgage shall always be redeemable and a mortgagors right to redeem shall neither be taken away nor be limited by any contract between the parties.

arguments.claim: 85-year term does not take away right to redeem, merely postpones its accrual until principal due; valid contract term

anchor.surface_text: The term providing that the right to redeem will arise after eightyfive years does not, of course, take away the mortgagors right to redeem and is not, therefore, in that sense, a clog on the equity of redemption. It does, however prevent accrual of the right to redeem for the period mentioned.

arguments.claim: No evidence term oppressive: suit after 47 years, common long terms in India, prior mortgage freed other property, interest not high, no financial embarrassment

anchor.surface_text: The suit for redemption was brought over forty-seven years after the date of the mortgage. It seems to us impossible that if the term was oppressive, that was not realised much earlier and the suit brought within a short time of the mortgage.

arguments.claim: Mortgagee right to enforce co-extensive with mortgagor right to redeem; no provision for mortgagee to demand early

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing in the mortgage instrument permitting the mortgagee to demand any money, and it is well settled that the mortgagees right to enforce the mortgage and the mortgagors right to redeem are coextensive.

arguments.claim: Repairs/new constructions clause requires payment per account produced, but only necessary ones; small property limits excess; safeguard for mortgagor

anchor.surface_text: We cannot lose sight of the fact that the mortgaged shop and the area of the land on which it stood were very small. It was not possible to spend a large. sum on repairs or construction there.

arguments.claim: Bargain reasonable, parties on equal footing; no evidence of mortgagor difficulties or unfair advantage

anchor.surface_text: We have no evidence in this case of the circumstances existing at the date of the mortgage as to the pecuniary condition of the mortgagor or as to anything else from which we may come to the conclusion that the mortgagee had taken advantage of the difficulties of the mortgagor and imposed a hard bargain on him.

arguments.claim: Prior mortgage does not indicate impecuniousness; freed kacheri for mortgagor benefit

anchor.surface_text: It was said that the fact that the property was subject to a prior mortgage at the date of the mortgage in suit indicates the impecunious position of the mortgagor. We are unable to agree with this contention.

arguments.claim: 85-year term not oppressive by length alone; no disadvantage shown

anchor.surface_text: The rule against clogs on the equity of redemption no doubt involves that the Courts have the power to relieve a party from his bargain. If he has agreed to forfeit wholly his right to redeem in certain circumstances, that agreement will be avoided.

arguments.claim: Invalidity of 6-month clause does not invalidate 85-year term; they stand apart

anchor.surface_text: We wish to observe here that the learned advocate did not contend that the invalidity, as we have earlier held, of the term taking away the right to redeem the mortgage after the period of six months makes the term fixing the period of the mortgage at eighty five years invalid.

holdings.text: The term providing that on failure to redeem within six months after 85 years, the mortgagor has no claim and the deed is deemed a sale cannot be sustained as it takes away the right to redeem.

anchor.surface_text: One thing, therefore, is clear, namely, that the term in the mortgage contract, that on the failure of the mortgagor to redeem the mortgage within the specified period of six months the mortgagor will have no claim over the mortgaged property, and the mortgage deed will be deemed to be a deed of sale in favour of the mortgagee, cannot be sustained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Violates rule that mortgage always redeemable ('once a mortgage always a mortgage'); extinguishes right after period, contrary to s.60 TPA which unqualifiedly allows redemption once arisen.

holdings.text: The invalidity of the six-month redemption limitation does not invalidate the 85-year term fixing when principal becomes due.

anchor.surface_text: We wish to observe here that the learned advocate did not contend that the invalidity, as we have earlier held, of the term taking away the right to redeem the mortgage after the period of six months makes the term fixing the period of the mortgage at eighty five years invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Terms distinct: one extinguishes right, other merely postpones accrual; invalidity of one does not affect the other.

holdings.text: The 85-year term does not clog the equity of redemption as it merely postpones accrual of right to redeem until principal due.

anchor.surface_text: The term providing that the right to redeem will arise after eightyfive years does not, of course, take away the mortgagors right to redeem and is not, therefore, in that sense, a clog on the equity of redemption. It does, however prevent accrual of the right to redeem for the period mentioned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Right to redeem arises only after principal due per s.60 TPA; parties free to contract due date; does not take away or limit existing right.

holdings.text: The 85-year term is not oppressive or unconscionable warranting equity relief; bargain reasonable and enforceable.

anchor.surface_text: We have no evidence in this case of the circumstances existing at the date of the mortgage as to the pecuniary condition of the mortgagor or as to anything else from which we may come to the conclusion that the mortgagee had taken advantage of the difficulties of the mortgagor and imposed a hard bargain on him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of mortgagor embarrassment/necessity; delay in suit (47 years); common long terms in India; freed prior mortgage on other property; interest not high; small property limits repairs; parties equal.

holdings.text: The suit for redemption is premature as the 85-year term has not expired and principal money not due.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, think that the bargain was a reasonable one and the eighty-five years term of the mortgage should be enforced. We then come to the conclusion that the suit was premature and must fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.60 TPA allows redemption only after principal due; 85-year term enforceable, sets due date August 1, 1984; suit in 1947 premature.

holdings.text: Under s.60 TPA, right to redeem exercisable only after principal money becomes due.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 60 of that Act, at any time after the principal money has become due, the mortgagor has a right on payment or tender of the mortgage money to require the mortgagee to reconvey the mortgage property to him. The right conferred by this section has been called the right to redeem and the appellant sought to enforce this right by his suit. Under this section, however, that right can be exercised only after the mortgage money has become due.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of statutory language; supported by precedent (Bakhtawari Begum).

anchor.surface_text: Bakhtawai-Begum v. HusainiKhanam  1   1913  L.R. 41 I.A. 84, 89.

precedents.cited_proposition: Ordinarily, and in the absence of a special condition entitling the mortgagor to redeem during the term for which the mortgage is created, the right of redemption can only arise on the expiration of the specified period.

anchor.surface_text: Santley v. Wilde  1  1899 2 Ch, 474.

precedents.cited_proposition: A mortgage is a conveyance of land or an assignment of chattles as a security for the payment of a debt or the discharge of some other obligation for which it is given. This is the idea of a mortgage and the security is redeemable on the payment or discharge of such debt or obligation, any provision to the contrary notwithstanding.
precedents.cited_holding: Any provision inserted to prevent redemption on payment or performance of the debt or obligation for which the security was given is what is meant by a clog or fetter on the equity of redemption and is therefore void. It follows from this, that once a mortgage always a mortgage.

precedents.citation: Mohammad Sher Khan v. Seth Swami Dayal  2   1921  L.R. 49 1,A. 60, 65.

anchor.surface_text: Mohammad Sher Khan v. Seth Swami Dayal  2   1921  L.R. 49 1,A. 60, 65.

precedents.case_name: Mohammad Sher Khan v. Seth Swami Dayal
precedents.cited_proposition: An anomalous mortgage enabling a mortgagee after a lapse of time and in the absence of redemption to enter and take the rents in satisfaction of the interest would be perfectly valid if it did not also hinder an existing right to redeem.
precedents.cited_holding: Under s. 60 of the Transfer of Property Act, once the right to redeem has arisen it cannot be taken away.

anchor.surface_text: Vermon v. Bethell  1   1762  2 Eden 110, 113 28 E.R. 838,839.

precedents.cited_proposition: This Court, as a Court of conscience, is very jealous of persons taking securities for a loan, and converting such securities into purchases.
precedents.cited_holding: A mortgagee can never provide at the time of making the loan for any event or condition on which the equity of redemption shall be discharged, and the conveyance absolute.

precedents.citation: G. and C. Kreglinger v. New Patagonia Meat and Cold Storage Company Ltd.  1

precedents.case_name: G. and C. Kreglinger v. New Patagonia Meat and Cold Storage Company Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: This jurisdiction was merely a special application of a more general power to relieve against penalties and to hold them into mere securities.
precedents.cited_holding: The end to accomplish which the jurisdiction has been evolved ought to govern and limit its exercise by equity judges. That end has always been to ascertain the real nature and substance of the transaction, and if it turned out to be in truth one of mortgage simply, to place it on that footing.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, think that the bargain was a reasonable one and the eighty-five years term of the mortgage should be enforced. We then come to the conclusion that the suit was premature and must fail.

anchor.surface_text: One thing, therefore, is clear, namely, that the term in the mortgage contract, that on the failure of the mortgagor to redeem the mortgage within the specified period of six months the mortgagor will have no claim over the mortgaged property, and the mortgage deed will be deemed to be a deed of sale in favour of the mortgagee, cannot be sustained.
We, therefore, think that the bargain was a reasonable one and the eighty-five years term of the mortgage should be enforced. We then come to the conclusion that the suit was premature and must fail.

anchor.surface_text: The term providing that the right to redeem will arise after eightyfive years does not, of course, take away the mortgagors right to redeem and is not, therefore, in that sense, a clog on the equity of redemption. It does, however prevent accrual of the right to redeem for the period mentioned.
We, therefore, think that the bargain was a reasonable one and the eighty-five years term of the mortgage should be enforced. We then come to the conclusion that the suit was premature and must fail.

edges.explanation: The holding denies equity relief by finding the term reasonable, undercutting the application of the equity relief concept against penalties in this mortgage case.

anchor.surface_text: We have no evidence in this case of the circumstances existing at the date of the mortgage as to the pecuniary condition of the mortgagor or as to anything else from which we may come to the conclusion that the mortgagee had taken advantage of the difficulties of the mortgagor and imposed a hard bargain on him.
We, therefore, think that the bargain was a reasonable one and the eighty-five years term of the mortgage should be enforced. We then come to the conclusion that the suit was premature and must fail.

edges.explanation: The holding denies relief consistent with the precedent's limitation on equity jurisdiction in similar mortgage contexts.

The precedent defines the scope of equity jurisdiction for relief against penalties ('this jurisdiction was merely a ...'), establishing the concept of equity relief against unconscionable mortgage terms.
The precedent's narrow view of equity jurisdiction supports the holding that no relief is warranted.
